text:
>> Sean: We've talked about Pascal.
What happened in Nottingham?

>> DFB: what happened in Nottingham?! 
Well, there we were,

at the end of the 1960s
turn of the 70s. I had been appointed to
do computer appreciation lectures for

Arts Professors and Lecturers and so on.
I did a little bit of programming [with them] and I

did it in Algol 60.
Algol60 was also what we used because,
at that time, we were just a little Computer

Group within the Maths department and
the other lecturer involved was Andy
Walker who,  well we

both agreed - he knew a lot more about
the alternatives than i did -

we could see Pascal was definitely a
contender [for the future]

but we also knew they [IFIP] were doing this
[language called] Algol 68.

And the attraction at the time  although
it wasn't really an attraction [as] we soon
realized was that Algol 68 had a

two-level grammar. So it wasn't
just Backus-Naur specification, which
was standard after Algol 60. Algol 68 took the view
that the way you could gain a lot more power

was not just to write down, by hand,
your BNF specification but to have a

master, supe,r all-action extra program 
[layer] at the top that
generated the BNF from other considerations.

The efforts of two-level grammars to
lead to a

new way of looking at things, appealed to only
a very narrow minority. What we [pragmatists] were
concerned with is: how did it compare with Pascal in
terms of the facilities it would be offering?

Was it a suitable language to be given
to computer science undergrads, and

specialist postgrads? And our view was:
"yes it was".

Next question - I can't emphasize this
strongly enough but I said it, I think in

the Pascal video:  if we're going to 
teach this, are

the compilers any good ?
Because we're going to have, you know, 50

or 60 undergrads
wanting to do courseworks with this.

It's no good if the compiler's flaky. It's got
to be robust,.

got to have good diagnostics; you've got
to be able to teach with it.

We could see good compilers being
developed with Pascal

and I said to Andy: "But what about Algol 68?"
He said: "Dave, you won't believe this
but there is a bunch of really talented computer

scientists at the Royal Radar Establishment 
in Malvern ... "

It sounded stupid at the time and
this was a bit before we ever got to

hear about Bell Labs - 
that was weird enough, you know, a secret

bunch of excellent computer scientists
buried inside a

research department for a telephone
company! Here were some extra,

super, computer scientists. Not so many of
them,  but buried in a Radar Establishment.

And these people are really competent.
They have a good track record.

And he said - you know
even now I mean I was talking [in] about

1970. He said: "Even in 1968
as it was announced, they had their

implementation working!"
I said: "Andy, right, so in principle it's

fine but here we are stuck on an ICL1906A.
We do not have an IBM !"

"No problem" [replied Andy], "because they are a UK
research establishment they have also been

stiffed with ICL hardware, like it or not"
"Oh" Ii said, "well that will

certainly help if we're all on the same 
machine ... "

So we got to know them at Malvern very
well indeed and rightly they were

celebrated for their
implementation of this Algol 68.

What did it do that helped? First of all it 
came up with
an idea of "types". Well, I'll call them types.

they preferred the 'in' phrase of modes
But i won't call them that because i'll

just confuse you.
Types. They were dead keen on types and

what Algol 68 could do,
you know, if you had an integer it could

now be called an 'int'. You could
abbreviate it.

But what about the place in memory that
holds your integer?

That's got an address - but we don't talk
about address[es],  we say

it *refers* to the integer it's where the
integer is stored.
So that was taken up, everybody liked that.

"It's the int -  but this place where it's stored?
It's got an address

And that address is a 'ref int'-  it refers
you to where the integer is".

You see? And then if you get a pointer to
that box, that's a pointer to a pointer

and that thing becomes a 'ref ref int' And
in the end you sound like a barking dog!
You know: "So i had this ref ref ref int

and i decided that i wanted to singly
dereference it and not

to doubly de-reference it right down to
the basic int

as the circumstance would seem to imply."
So do you know what I did? Ii used a cast -

where you pour your hot metal into a
mould and it comes out in the shape you

want it?
And I said: " ...  I'm going to cast it down

just to to ref ref int -  not all the way
back down to int".

All this kind of stuff. Andy [Walker] reassured 
me. Quite rightly he said:

It [Algol 68] does do bytes and it does do bits
and all this kind of stuff". [By contrast] in your

Pascal compiler you can't get down to bit-level
manipulation.

The implementation team at
Malvern could use ... I think they used their
Algol 60 compiler to implement Algol 68.

They pretty well got their compiler
working on the day the {Algol 68] report

was released. Because of course they were
on the inside track; they knew what was
going on. here were a few restrictions on it.

It was what's called a single-pass compiler
for speed.

And that meant sometimes declaring your
structures [e.g. for types] was a bit awkward.

And they had banned certain things that
were appearing in [full] Algol 68

that they thought would be expensive to
do. It was called Algol 68R. And i think

'R' meant 'restricted'. Andy and i we were 
very happy

with it. We could make [it] a success.
But - because you're going to ask me -

surely it's all right for hardcore
computer scientists

to be casting ref ref ref ints down to
ref ints

[But] how do mere mortals cope with that? And
we were very alive to the 'mere mortals'.

We weren't just doing hardcore computer
scientists.

We were involved in 'outreach' Masters
courses
which wanted a bit of programming towards
making this be a digital business person

Or being on a programming team in a
commercial environment. And i think we

both agreed
that a good choice for the absolute

non-specialists but it wouldn't scare
them too much would be Pascal

so we did actually run both. We ran
Pascal for many years, I think, in our

so-called 'conversion Master's' degrees.
but we kept Algol 68 for the hardcore stuff.

>> Sean: Was that something you could do
relatively straightforwardly

from an infrastructure point of view?
Because i'm not talking about PCs on

every desk in this era ?
>> DFB: No, fortunately, with the Algol 68R
compilers we could have people feeding in

Algol 68 jobs on cards into the 1906A
but equally ICL had their own Pascal
compiler. One way or another there were good
enough compilers. Yes, I mean, we were teaching

Pascal, I think, into the early 90s.
We knew that, coming up on the rails

alongside, of course,
was that C from the mid- to late-  70s

almost was getting better
and better. C has got input from Algol,

Algol 68 and also, but principally, from
BCPL.

And guess what? Two of the people who
designed BCPL were also on the Algol 60
committee,basically saying: " ... it's not quite the way

to do it - BCPL is a lot better!" And all
this kind of stuff.

Because of that rallying point, way back,
of Algol 60,

it you could transfer between these
dialects

fairly easily. You probably had
"theological" opinions about the right and

just way forward, and you deprecated
all of the other approaches, but

nevertheless you knew you were basically
in the same playground.

But you were just making different
decisions because of the different,
you know, clientele involved, I think, too.

One of the things that does need to be
said and it brought it home to Andy and
me, is that the implementation team at
Malvern, for Algol 68R was, Ian Currie, John Morison

and Susan Bond. Ian and John, I think, were
the driving force behind Coral 64 their

early adventure [system programming language]
But Sue Bond was an absolutely vital

member of that team for Algol 68.
She was an absolute rock of that team

[and] gets under-appreciated because she
suffered from what we've referred to,

I think obliquely in these [video] lectures.
[It] started at Bletchley Park.

The Joan Clark effect. Joan Clark was a
highly qualified mathematician.

[She] studied at Cambridge with Alan Turing.
Alan Turing wanted her on his team at
Bletchley Park. Big Problem. They couldn't pay her enough

because she was a woman and [a] Cryptographer
post was for men only!

So they had to get round it by
saying that she was a Linguist.

[Buty by]  reclassifying her they could get her the
right money. I think a similar thing

happened with Sue Bond. 
The only way she could make further

progress was to become more of an
administrator,

which she did. And she made a very
successful career for herself [ending up as
Superintendent of Computing and Software Research].

Here's just a moment when we should be
celebrating our women computer
scientists they were absolutely equal colleagues
and, you know, deserve to get a lot more
respect than they do - even now.
